pros: SPU has a great staff, and you will find lots of kind people to work alongside. I greatly enjoyed working here, as I made lots of friends, and had plenty of opportunities to grow professionally.

review_title: Stable job but not for anyone with ambition.
job_title: Technology Support Analyst in Seattle, WA
pros:
Job is very stable. 
The community very much tries to be a family and they do care about you. 
Not a very high stress position.
cons:
Always a fire to put out. 
Always behind in tech due to budget and management limitations.
Revolving door of employees in the analyst position due to no career development. 
Constant heaping of work on top of your already large workload. 
No clearly defined lines and areas of work so scope creep becomes real. 
Asked to learn and maintain systems and code that others have left behind years ago with no documentation.
No raises for years.

review_title: Christian organization with low pay but some benefit perks
pros: Full-time employees receive a free bus pass, automatic 9% retirement contribution, and tuition discount that increases according to years of service.
cons: The pay for staff members is not livable by Seattle standards, and there is little room for growth. The university has a long way to go in terms of equity and inclusion, and does not hire LGBTQ employees. Applicants are required to sign a human sexuality statement (dated as last revised in 2004) and a code of conduct before hire. The code of conduct states that SPU staff cannot have sex outside of marriage, and human sexuality statement says the church views marriage as between a man and woman only. Taken together, this means an LGBTQ individual--even if they were married to an individual of the same sex--could not be hired unless they were celibate. However, because hiring teams cannot ask questions about sexual activity, any candidate who reveals that they are LGBT will be dismissed out of the gate.

pros: Good professors, they care about your work
cons: Student may be lazy depending on the subject

pros: Training, friendly coworkers, on campus

pros: great culture to work in

job_title: Graduate Admissions Advisor in Seattle, WA
pros: Great and caring culture. Opportunities for growth

job_title: Technology Support Analyst II in Seattle, WA
pros:
1)SPU is a family and is very warm and welcoming of new people.
2)If you are a person of Christian faith, there really is no better place to work as it is not only welcomed but celebrated here.
3)Competitive pay rates
4) Positions are designed for people to spend a career in. No throw away roles. 

Overall it's a pretty great place to work. Lots of PTO, work/life balance is something constantly emphasized, and most everyone is pleasant to work with. The position I am currently in is challenging, ever changing, and really great for someone wanting to learn a lot about a lot of things.
cons:
1) Health benefits are not that great and cost a lot for a family considering the  job is located in the heart of Seattle
2)Raises are annual but small. Most bumps in compensation are from position advancement.
3)Practices can sometimes feel archaic. 
4)Position advancement can sometimes be judged on time spent at SPU instead of work performance.

review_title: I love working with the people at SPU!
job_title: Data Entry Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: I enjoy how we are treated as Data Entry Students. We have a lot of freedom to get the work done on our schedule and it makes the whole experience much more enjoyable. There is also a lot of understanding for us students who are busy and that makes scheduling weekly hours easy.
cons: The work can be incredibly routine and boring. This is just apart of doing data entry 10-20 hours a week but it does become dull. Also the size of projects can be overwhelming and slightly unrealistic.

review_title: Good place to work but management somewhat lacking in Computer and Information Systems
pros: Loved the people and benefits of SPU. Working conditions were wonderful and interactions with faculty and staff was great.
cons: Some managers were out to create little empires for themselves. Upper management was micromanaging of lower managers in hiring people from other teams and projects. If you didn't like the decision made that was too bad. No loyalty among the lower managers which was pretty pathetic for a Christian college. I've seen too many good employees get the shaft from this group to ever recommend looking for employment here.  This is too bad because there are a lot of good people working in other departments.

pros: Affirming colleagues practicing Christians in that they tend to be charitable and welcoming, not your Ted Cruz evangelicals; small, pretty university in an idyllic setting - Seattle is both naturally beautiful and super civilized, with great schools within driving distance of this workplace.
cons: An evangelical institution may not be everyone's cup of tea. The students are ill-prepared, entitled and fragile, but this may be increasingly true of students everywhere; for this particular professor, teaching students elsewhere was much easier though; SPU students tend to feel gypped by the high fees and their own poor performance. This is not the fault of the excellent faculty, but the students tend to vent in their evaluations of faculty. I got decent ratings from SPU students but stellar ratings elsewhere.

pros: This university is a great place to work with amazing people and a great mission.  The pay is nowhere near market, particularly for specialized areas of expertise and the High Deductible Health Care Package, though common in academics, is not competitve for the region.
cons: Sometimes the organization can be a little too "grace filled" and not hold employees accountable, and there really isn't much in the way of significant raises or bonuses based on performance.  So two employees in the exact same roles -- one doing very well and one performing poorly -- will make around the same pay with no review or consequences for the poor performance.  Fortunately, the university is working on the performance review portion of this problem.

review_title: A great University to work for
pros: This company had a great atmosphere. They really took care of their employees and it shows by how long people have been working there. Great employee events, and great campus vibe.
cons: There wasn't much room to grow in this job. I am not sure it is representative of all the positions at spu. But it seemed that people had the same title for 20+ years. Not much mixing it up, or getting promotions. A lot of people were brought in form the outside rather than promoting from within.

pros: Very rewarding position helping registered nurses with AA degree obtain their Bachelor's Degree in Nursing in a two year, off-campus program.  Included student admissions, counseling, recruiting events, evaluation of credits (including international), class and faculty scheduling for each cohort, graduation "pinning" ceremonies.
cons: Funding for the program was 3rd party and during the economic downturn in 2009, the program suffered and funding was reduced significantly.  My position could no longer be supported.  An on-campus RN to MSN program was created that I was not qualified for without an advanced degree.  The program director had to manage the entire program, including teaching courses.

review_title: SPU is a great place to work
pros:
-Great community/atmosphere
-Work around your class schedule
-Supervisors are very helpful and understanding
-The supervisors and other staff let you know that you're appreciated and needed
cons: The only con is the fact that you're an assistant and have to take care of the projects that nobody really wants to do. That's the same with any assistant job. I really enjoyed working at SPU and don't have any bad reviews because it was an amazing experience

pros: Wonderful people; great mission; an organization that's small enough to let you be scrappy and really spread your wings, but large enough that you have support in your efforts
cons: Salary can't compete with other Seattle employers; location makes it difficult to access via public transportation; antiquated statement on human sexuality

review_title: I had a great experience and gained a lot of experience.
pros: The pros for working at SPU are the great work environment, people and ethical values of the organization. Everyone wants you to be successful both in your work and in your life and care deeply about you.
cons: There aren't many cons for working at Seattle Pacific University other than there are some inter department politics that can be frustrating to deal with. This is nothing compared to other organization though.

review_title: Beautiful Campus, great benefits, sorta ok pay
pros: Beautiful campus setting. Great benefits including good insurance (medical, dental, eye), automatic retirement pay (don't even need to match it!). Access to facilities (weight/cardio rooms, basketball gym, play fields, cafeterias, etc), and events (chapel services, all-campus events {which often include free food}, great speakers, etc). Great people to work with.
cons: The pay isn't great and that might be expected (for a private school), however, the retirement benefits make up for that a lot. Like anywhere, organizational politics happen.

review_title: Excellent Community and fun place to work!
pros: The SPU community is full of genuinely nice people. Many people that work at SPU end up staying for 10-20 years!
cons: Salaries are not very competitive with other similar jobs in the area. Internal promotions are rare. If you are happy with your job and salary, this is a great place to work; if you want to increase in salary or advance to a higher job level or title, you will likely to need to leave SPU to do so.

pros: Supportive environment with positive attitude towards workers.  High base pay - higher than minimum wage in the city, and will be increasing as minimum wage increases.
cons: Dogmatic beliefs - require you to sign waiver stating "Christian beliefs".  Technically discriminatory against non-Christians.  Not an entirely secure timesheet system for students.

job_title: Assistant Director of Residence Life in Seattle, WA
pros: The professional staff were incredibly dedicated to their work. Administration and general students experience some divide, but residential and student life programs are strong connectors to community.
cons: Challenges that the institution has facing them regarding treatment of marginalized groups. Particularly in policy decisions that reflect foundations of university but need to adapt to be more inclusive.

review_title: SPU offers a wide variety of jobs for students, many pertaining to specific majors.
pros:
-Many available jobs
-Some jobs are major-specific and contribute valuable resume-building experience
-Ideal location for a student without a car
cons:
-As far as I've experienced, SPU is not very hands-on with it's employed students about helping them find jobs in the real world
-Students often underpaid for the amount of hours worked

review_title: Convenient work for students, but limited pay and hours (Dining Services)
pros: The work you have is very convenient. It is easy to schedule around classes. Shifts tend to be shorter and fit in between your schedule.
cons: Low pay and no tips for student workers. Hours were scarce for the employee base.

review_title: Great co-workers, not so great management (Student Financial Services)
job_title: Student Financial Services in Seattle, WA
pros: There is strong community aspect. People truly care about one another and the students who attend SPU.
cons: The pay is low, not much opportunity for growth. Some managers are difficult to communicate with, work for. If you're not Christian, the mandatory church is not so fun.

review_title: good community at Seattle Pacific to start your career
pros: Good, safe community. Great mission and respectable environment. The campus is beautiful and you can tell they spend a lot of money/time into keeping it nice. The new President is wonderful and evidently a smart man with many goals. SPU is in good hands.
cons: Since the community is so small, you have to be careful about every word you say.

review_title: Small and very fun IT team. SysAdmins get to get their feet dirty in pretty much everything.

pros:
Broad array of technologies to work on
young atmosphere since you're surrounded by college kids
Good management
cons: The pay is very low. Don't work in IT if you want to make money. Managers make out OK

pros:
Because it is a small school leadership is accessible.
SPU has staff from a fairly diverse background and is growing to be inclusive and both implicitly as well as explicitly non discriminatory
cons: There can be some discontinuity between different levels of authority from student to president.

pros: Wonderful coffee culture. Loved the spiritual vibes and relationships with others. Really felt encouraged by those I was with.
cons: Definitely feeling overwhelmed sometimes because of the smaller workforce in our office. But I guess that means more opportunity to learn for me.

review_title: Great place to work for students, but don't expect to make much money
pros: Short commute for most, understanding supervisors, flexible around school assignments, similar coworkers
cons: While working at Seattle Pacific University is very convenient for most students, don't expect to make much more than minimum for almost every job.

pros: Working with an amazing group of caring professionals.
cons: Salaries below average for high cost areas like Seattle, new healthcare plan is worse than the one we had before.

pros: This job offered invaluable experience. The camaraderie felt between co workers and supervisors made this job incredibly rewarding and life changing
